2015|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web |title=The Coatbridge Irish|url=http://www.stpatricksdayfestivalcoatbridge.org/History/Main/History.htm |website=St Patrick's Day Festival Coatbridge |accessdate=17 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070708051820/http://www.stpatricksdayfestivalcoatbridge.org/History/Main/History.htm |archivedate=8 July 2007|df=dmy-all}} also has [[St. Patrick's Day festival Coatbridge|a Saint Patrick's Day Festival]] which includes celebrations and parades in the town centre.{{cite web |title=St Patrick's Day in Coatbridge, Scotland |url=https://comingtoscotland.wordpress.com/ |date=March 14, 2015 |website=Coming to Scotland |accessdate=17 March 2015}} [[Glasgow]] has a considerably large Irish population; due, for the most part, to the Irish immigration during the 19th century. This immigration was the main cause in raising the population of Glasgow by over 100,000 people.{{cite web |author=Michael Moss |work=The Glasgow Story |url=http://www.theglasgowstory.com/storyc.php |title=Industrial Revolution: 1770s to 1830s |accessdate=17 March 2012}} Due to this large Irish population, there are many Irish-themed pubs and Irish interest groups who hold yearly celebrations on St Patrick's day in Glasgow. Glasgow has held a yearly St Patrick's Day parade and festival since 2007.{{cite web |title=Welcome to the Glasgow St. Patrick's Festival 2018 Website |url=http://www.glasgowstpatricksfestival.co.uk/ |website=Glasgow's St. Patrick's Festival |publisher=St. Patrick's Festival Committee |accessdate=20 March 2018}} ====Switzerland==== While Saint Patrick's Day in Switzerland is commonly celebrated on 17 March with festivities similar to those in neighbouring central European countries, it is not unusual for Swiss students to organise celebrations in their own living spaces on St Patrick's Eve. Most popular are usually those in Zurich's [[Aussersihl|Kreis 4]]. Traditionally, guests also contribute with beverages and dress in green.{{cite web |url=https://www.amiv.ethz.ch/content/st-patricks-eve-celebrations-2012-zürich |title=St. Patrick's Eve Celebrations 2012 in Zürich |language=de |publisher=Zurich Student Association |accessdate=20 February 2012}} ===Asia=== ====Japan==== [[File:Saint Patricks Day in Motomachi Yokohama.jpg|thumb|Saint Patrick's Day in [[Motomachi, Yokohama]]]] St Patrick's parades are now held in many locations across Japan.{{cite web |url=http://st-patricks-day.com/st_patricks_day_parades_asia_japan.html |title=Saint Patrick's Day Parades & Events in Japan |accessdate=24 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130508140202/http://st-patricks-day.com/st_patricks_day_parades_asia_japan.html |archivedate=8 May 2013 }} The first parade, in Tokyo, was organised by The Irish Network Japan (INJ) in 1992. ====Korea==== The Irish Association of Korea has celebrated Saint Patrick's Day since 1976 in [[Seoul]], the capital city of [[South Korea]]. The place of the parade and festival has been moved from [[Itaewon]] and [[Daehangno]] to [[Cheonggyecheon]].{{cite web |url=http://www.iak.co.kr/event/event.php |title=Saint Patrick's Day in Korea Event Page |publisher=Irish Association of Korea |accessdate=17 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100314060945/http://www.iak.co.kr/event/event.php |archivedate=14 March 2010 |df=dmy-all }} ====Malaysia==== In [[Malaysia]], the St Patrick's Society of Selangor, founded in 1925, organises a yearly St Patrick's Ball, described as the biggest St Patrick's Day celebration in Asia. [[Guinness Anchor Berhad]] also organises 36 parties across the country in places like the [[Klang Valley]], [[Penang]], [[Johor Bahru]], Malacca, [[Ipoh]], [[Kuantan]], [[Kota Kinabalu]], [[Miri, Malaysia|Miri]] and [[Kuching]]. ===Caribbean=== ====Montserrat==== The tiny island of [[Montserrat]] is known as the "Emerald Island of the [[Caribbean Sea|Caribbean]]" because of its founding by [[Irish immigration to Saint Kitts and Nevis|Irish refugees from Saint Kitts and Nevis]]. Montserrat is one of three places where St Patrick's Day is a public holiday, along with Ireland and the Canadian province of Newfoundland & Labrador. The holiday in Montserrat also commemorates a failed slave uprising that occurred on 17 March 1768.{{Cite book |title= Gallery Montserrat: some prominent people in our history |last= Fergus|first= Howard A.|year=1996 |publisher=Canoe Press University of West Indies |location= |isbn=976-8125-25-X |page=83 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2DD81ZHWhxgC&pg=PA83 |accessdate=24 December 2010}} ===International Space Station=== [[File:Chris Hadfield in the Space Station on Saint Patrick's Day.jpg|thumb|Chris Hadfield wearing green in the International Space Station on St Patrick's Day, 2013]] Astronauts on board the [[International Space Station]] have celebrated the festival in different ways. Irish-American [[Catherine Coleman]] played a hundred-year-old flute belonging to [[Matt Molloy]] and a tin whistle belonging to [[Paddy Moloney]], both members of the Irish music group [[The Chieftains]], while floating weightless in the space station on Saint Patrick's Day in 2011.{{cite web |author=Tariq Malik |url=http://www.space.com/11159-irish-astronaut-stpatricks-day-flute-music.html |title=Irish Astronaut in Space Gives St. Patrick's Day Musical Flair |work=Space.com |date=17 March 2011}}{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vX-5n_YcxgQ |title=St. Patrick's Day Greeting From Space |publisher=NASA TV video |date=17 March 2011}}{{cite web |author=Diarmaid Fleming |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/molloy-s-flute-to-help-irish-music-breach-the-final-frontier-1.687275 |title=Molloy's flute to help Irish music breach the final frontier |work=Irish Times |date=15 December 2010}} Her performance was later included in a track called "The Chieftains in Orbit" on the group's album, ''[[Voice of Ages]]''.{{cite web |author=Brian Boyd |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/culture/music/2.659/chieftains-call-up-to-an-army-of-indie-admirers-1.479104 |title=Chieftains' call-up to an army of indie admirers |work=Irish Times |date=10 March 2012}} [[Chris Hadfield]] took photographs of Ireland from earth orbit, and a picture of himself wearing green clothing in the space station, and posted them online on Saint Patrick's Day in 2013. He also posted online a recording of himself singing "[[Danny Boy]]" in space.{{cite web |author=Ronan McGreevy |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/out-of-this-world-rendition-of-danny-boy-marks-st-patrick-s-day-in-space-1.1328923 |title=Out of this world rendition of Danny Boy marks St Patrick’s Day in space |work=The Irish Times |date=17 March 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://w.soundcloud.com/player/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fapi.soundcloud.com%2Ftracks%2F83635601 |title=Astronaut Chris Hadfield singing "Danny Boy" on the International Space Station |work=Soundcloud |date=17 March 2013}} ===North America=== ====Canada==== [[File:St. Patrick's Day Montreal 2007.jpg|thumb|Montreal hosts one of the longest-running and largest St Patrick's Day parades in North America.]] One of the longest-running and largest St Patrick's Day parades in North America occurs each year in [[Montreal]],{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/montreal-celebrates-191st-st-patrick-s-day-parade-sunday-1.2568446 |title=Montreal celebrates 191st St. Patrick's Day parade Sunday |website=CBC News |publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation |date=11 March 2014 |accessdate=17 March 2014}} whose [[Flag of Montreal|city flag]] includes a [[shamrock]] in its lower-right quadrant. The yearly celebration has been organised by the United Irish Societies of Montreal since 1929. The parade has been held yearly without interruption since 1824. St Patrick's Day itself, however, has been celebrated in Montreal since as far back as 1759 by Irish soldiers in the Montreal Garrison following the British conquest of New France. In [[Saint John, New Brunswick]] St. Patrick's Day is celebrated as a week-long celebration. Shortly after the [[JP Collins Celtic Festival]] is an Irish festival celebrating Saint John's Irish heritage. The festival is named for a young Irish doctor James Patrick Collins who worked on [[Partridge Island (Saint John County)]] quarantine station tending to sick Irish immigrants before he died there himself. In Manitoba, the Irish Association of Manitoba runs a yearly three-day festival of music and culture based around St Patrick's Day.{{cite web |url=http://www.irishassociation.ca/ |title=Coming Events |website=Irish Association of Manitoba |accessdate=19 March 2018}} In 2004, the CelticFest Vancouver Society organised its first yearly festival in downtown Vancouver to celebrate the [[Celtic Nations]] and their cultures. This event, which includes a parade, occurs each year during the weekend nearest St Patrick's Day.{{cite web |url=http://www.celticfestvancouver.com |title=CelticFest Vancouver |publisher=Celticfest Vancouver |accessdate=19 March 2018}} In [[Quebec City]], there was a parade from 1837 to 1926. The [[Quebec City St-Patrick Parade]] returned in 2010 after more than 84 years. For the occasion, a portion of the New York Police Department Pipes and Drums were present as special guests. There has been a parade held in Toronto since at least 1863.{{cite journal |last=Cottrell |first=Michael |url=http://pi.library.yorku.ca/ojs/index.php/hssh/article/viewFile/16699/15557 |title=St. Patrick's Day Parades in Nineteenth-Century Toronto: A Study of Immigrant Adjustment and Elite Control |journal=Histoire sociale – Social History |volume=XXV |issue=49 |date=May 1992 |pages=57–73 |accessdate=17 March 2015}} There is a large parade in the city's downtown on the Sunday before 17 March which attracts over 100,000 spectators.{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} The [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] hockey team was known as the [[Toronto St. Patricks]] from 1919 to 1927, and wore green jerseys. In 1999, when the Maple Leafs played on St Patrick's Day, they wore green St Patrick's retro uniforms.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} Some groups, notably [[Guinness]], have lobbied to make Saint Patrick's Day a national holiday.{{cite web|url=http://www.proposition317.com/Gateway.aspx |title=Guinness |publisher=Proposition 3–17 |accessdate=17 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323192927/http://www.proposition317.com/Gateway.aspx |archivedate=23 March 2010 |df= }} In March 2009, the [[Calgary Tower]] changed its top exterior lights to new green CFL bulbs just in time for St Patrick's Day. Part of an environmental non-profit organisation's campaign (Project Porchlight), the green represented environmental concerns. Approximately 210 lights were changed in time for Saint Patrick's Day, and resembled a [[Leprechaun]]'s hat. After a week, white CFLs took their place. The change was estimated to save the Calgary Tower some $12,000 and reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 104 tonnes.{{cite web|last=Bevan |first=Alexis |url=http://www.calgaryherald.com/news/Calgary+Tower+gets+full+green+bulb+treatment/1378992/story.html |title=Calgary Tower gets full green bulb treatment |work=Calgary Herald |date=11 March 2009 |accessdate=17 March 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090330025307/http://www.calgaryherald.com/news/Calgary%2BTower%2Bgets%2Bfull%2Bgreen%2Bbulb%2Btreatment/1378992/story.html |archivedate=30 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ====United States==== [[File:ChicagoStPatricksDay2015.jpg|thumb|The [[Chicago River]] [[Dye|dyed]] green{{cite web |url=http://abc7chicago.com/news/crowds-gather-for-st-patricks-day-celebrations-downtown/1242900/ |title=Crowds gather for St. Patrick's Day celebrations downtown |last=Holmes |first=Evelyn |date=12 March 2016 |publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]] |accessdate=13 March 2016 |quote=Large crowds gathered for Saturday's St. Patrick's Day festivities downtown. Although St. Patrick's Day is actually on a Thursday this year, Chicago will be marking the day all weekend long. Some started the day at Mass at Old St. Patrick's Church in the city's West Loop neighborhood. Spectators gathered along the riverfront in the Loop for the annual dyeing of the Chicago River, which began at 9 am}}]] {{Main|Saint Patrick's Day in the United States}} St Patrick's Day, while not a legal holiday in the United States, is nonetheless widely recognised and observed throughout the country as a celebration of Irish and Irish-American culture. Celebrations include prominent displays of the colour green, religious observances, numerous parades, and copious consumption of alcohol. The holiday has been celebrated in North America since the late 18th century. ===South America=== ====Argentina==== [[File:Día de San Patricio Buenos Aires 2.jpg|thumb|Celebrations in [[Buenos Aires]] centre on Reconquista street.]] In Buenos Aires, a party is held in the downtown street of Reconquista, where there are several Irish pubs;{{cite web|url=http://www.sanpatricio2009.com.ar/index.htm |title=Saint Patrick's Day in Argentina |publisher=Sanpatricio2009.com.ar |date=17 March 2009 |accessdate=17 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130727025139/http://sanpatricio2009.com.ar/index.htm |archivedate=27 July 2013 |df= }}{{youtube|Df8ATMkkqWE|Saint Patrick's Day in Argentina}}. {{Retrieved|accessdate=17 March 2009}} in 2006, there were 50,000 people in this street and the pubs nearby.{{cite web|url=http://www.clarin.com/diario/2006/03/18/laciudad/h-06401.htm |title=San Patricio convocó a una multitud |publisher=Clarin.com |date=18 March 2006 |accessdate=17 March 2012}} Neither the Catholic Church nor the [[Irish settlement in Argentina|Irish community]], the fifth largest in the world outside Ireland,{{Cite journal |title=Los Irlandeses en la Argentina |journal=Familia, journal of the Ulster Historical Foundation |volume=2 | number=8 |year=1992 |first=Pat |last=Nally |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/ancestor/magazine/articles/uhf_argentina1.htm |accessdate=6 November 2010}} take part in the organisation of the parties. ==Criticism== [[File:Marnie the Dog celebrating St. Patrick's Day.jpg|thumb|upright|Some argue Saint Patrick's Day has become too commercialised and tacky]] St Patrick's Day celebrations have been criticised, particularly for their association with [[public drunkenness]] and [[disorderly conduct]]. Some argue that the festivities have become too [[Commercialism|commercialised]] and tacky,{{sfnp|Cronin|Adair|2002 |p=240}}{{cite web |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/opinion/columnists/fionola-meredith/time-to-banish-perpetually-offended-elements-in-society-29142031.html |title=Time to banish perpetually offended elements in society |author=Fionola Meredith |work=[[Belfast Telegraph]] |date=21 March 2013}} and have strayed from their original purpose of honouring St Patrick and Irish heritage.{{cite web |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/st-patrick-s-day-celebrates-the-role-of-all-us-migrants-1.483637 |title=St Patrick's Day celebrates the role of all US migrants |author=James Flannery |work=[[The Irish Times]] |date=17 March 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/irishamerican_catholics_negotiate_st._patricks_day_and_holy_week_conflict |title=Irish-American Catholics negotiate St. Patrick’s Day and Holy Week conflict |work=[[Catholic News Agency]] |date=7 March 2008}}{{sfnp|Cronin|Adair|2002 |p=240}} Journalist [[Niall O'Dowd]] has criticised attempts to recast St Patrick's Day as a celebration of [[multiculturalism]] rather than a celebration of Irishness.{{cite web |title=Please, let's keep political correctness out of Saint Patrick's Day |url=http://www.irishcentral.com/opinion/niallodowd/please-lets-keep-political-correctness-out-of-saint-patricks-day--pressure-mounts-to-make-it-about-more-than-just-the-irish-in-america-143292966-238125081.html |author=Niall O'Dowd |work=IrishCentral |date=18 March 2012}} St Patrick's Day celebrations have also been criticised for fostering demeaning stereotypes of Ireland and [[Irish people]].{{sfnp|Cronin|Adair|2002 |p=240}} An example is the wearing of '[[leprechaun]] outfits',{{cite web |author=Ian O'Doherty |url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/columnists/ian-odoherty/st-patricks-day-when-everyones-proud-to-be-a-stereotype-31072014.html |title=St Patrick's Day – when everyone's proud to be a stereotype |work=[[Irish Independent]] |date=17 March 2015}} which are based on derogatory 19th century caricatures of the Irish.{{Cite book|title=Gold: A Cultural Encyclopedia |last=Venable |first=Shannon |year=2011 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |pages=196–197}} In the run up to St Patrick's Day 2014, the [[Ancient Order of Hibernians]] successfully campaigned to stop major American retailers from selling novelty merchandise that promoted negative Irish stereotypes.{{cite web |author=Jennifer Harper |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/mar/16/weary-drunk-leprechauns-irish-americans-protest-th |title=O’Done with It: Irish Americans protest ‘negative stereotyping’ as bawdy drunks |work=[[The Washington Times]] |date=16 March 2014|accessdate=23 March 2018}} Some{{who|date=July 2018}} have described St Patrick's Day celebrations outside Ireland as displays of "[[Plastic Paddy]]ness"; where foreigners [[Cultural appropriation|appropriate]] and misrepresent [[Irish culture]], claim Irish identity, and enact Irish stereotypes.{{cite web |author-link=Alex Massie (journalist) |author=Massie, Alex |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/217081/erin-go-argh-alex-massie |title=Erin Go Argh! |work=[[National Review Online]] |date=17 March 2006}} [[LGBT rights in the United States|LGBT groups in the US]] were banned from marching in St. Patrick's Day parades in [[New York City]] and [[Boston]], resulting in the landmark [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] decision of ''[[Hurley v. Irish-American Gay, Lesbian, & Bisexual Group of Boston]]''. In New York City, the ban was lifted in 2014,{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/04/nyregion/new-york-st-patricks-day-parade-organizers-lift-ban-on-gay-groups.html?_r=0 |last=Santora |first=Mark |title=Gay Groups to March in St. Patrick's Day Parade as Ban Falls |work=The New York Times |date=3 September 2014 |accessdate=17 March 2016}} but LGBT groups still find that barriers to participation exist.{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/huff-wires/20140903/us--nyc-st-patrick-s-day-parade-gays/ |last=Fitzgerald |first=Jim |title=Gays Scoff at NY St. Patrick's Day Parade Decision |work=Huffington Post |date=3 September 2014 |accessdate=17 March 2016 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324104033/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/huff-wires/20140903/us--nyc-st-patrick-s-day-parade-gays/ |archive-date=24 March 2016}} In Boston, the ban on LGBT group participation was lifted in 2015.{{cite news |url=http://time.com/3745215/gay-groups-boston-st-patricks-parade/ |last=Worland |first=Justin |title=Boston Sees Historic St. Patrick's Day Parade |work=Time |date=15 March 2015 |accessdate=17 March 2016}} ==Sports events== * Traditionally the [[All-Ireland Senior Club Football Championship]] and [[All-Ireland Senior Club Hurling Championship]] are held on Saint Patrick's Day in [[Croke Park]], Dublin. The [[Interprovincial Championship]] was previously held on 17 March but this was switched to games being played in Autumn. *The [[Leinster Schools Rugby Senior Cup]], [[Munster Schools Rugby Senior Cup]] and [[Ulster Schools Senior Cup]] are held on Saint Patrick's Day. The [[Connacht Schools Rugby Senior Cup]] is held on the weekend before Saint Patrick's Day. * The [[Saint Patrick's Day Test]] is an international [[rugby league]] tournament that is played between the [[United States national rugby league team|US]] and [[Ireland national rugby league team|Ireland]]. The competition was first started in 1995 with Ireland winning the first two tests with the US winning the last 4 in 2000, 2002, 2003 and 2004. The game is usually held on or around 17 March to coincide with Saint Patrick's Day.{{cite web |last=Lowe |first=Brian |url=http://www.wearerugby.com/news/articles/tomahawks-host-ireland |title=Tomahawks To Host Ireland |website=We Are Rugby |date=9 December 2010 |accessdate=31 March 2011 |dead-url=usurped |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110718010215/http://www.wearerugby.com/news/articles/tomahawks-host-ireland |archivedate=18 July 2011}} * The [[major professional sports leagues of the United States and Canada]] that play during March often wear special [[third jersey]]s to acknowledge the holiday. Examples include the [[Buffalo Sabres]] (who have worn special Irish-themed practice jerseys), [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] (who wear [[Toronto St. Patricks]] throwbacks), [[New York Knicks]], [[Toronto Raptors]], and most [[Major League Baseball]] teams. The [[New Jersey Devils]] have worn their green-and-red throwback jerseys on or around Saint Patrick's Day in recent years.{{cite news | url = http://www.nj.com/devils/index.ssf/2015/03/how_do_the_devils_feel_about_wearing_the_green_and.html | title = How do the Devils feel about wearing the green and red retro jerseys? | work = NJ.com | The '''San Sebastian’s Walk''' is a religious catholic event with ecological and sport characteristics, which takes place the 20th of January of each year in the outskirts of the city of [[Maracay]], [[Aragua State]], in [[Venezuela]].
The route of this peregrination begins in [[El Limón, Venezuela|El Limón]] and finishes in the Main Church of [[Ocumare de la Costa]]. The route is 29.09 miles long crossing the mountains of the [[Henri Pittier National Park]] using the only paved route that unites the city of [[Maracay]] with the coastal zone of Venezuela.
==History==
The origin of this event is associated to Celso Bethencourt, who was born in [[Canary Islands]], Spain, and to Francesco Centrone, originally from Italy, who made this first route walking with no stops to fulfill a religious promise to Saint Sebastian, finishing their long walk the 20th of January 1987 in approximately 12 hours, after this first peregrination Francesco Centrone continued making this passage, every year on the same day; year after year making the long walk with family and friends, forming little by little a tradition. In 1996 Centrone and a group created the Foundation Peregrination Saint Sebastian to continue with the walk. The Foundation manages the donations and the money to support social programs in the town of [[Ocumare de la Costa]] and to foster ecological plans on the route.
==Route==
The route consists on 7.8 miles of ascent, 12.4 miles of slope and 6.2 miles of level ground. The route traditionally has multiple points at which assistance is available.
==Details== There is a time limit to accomplish this walk of 12 hours. Starting time is at 6:00 a.m.

Adolf Hitler's pet|resting_place=|resting_place_coordinates=|height=}}'''Saturn''' (born 1936) is an [[American alligator]] residing in the [[Moscow Zoo]]. He is most notable as the subject of an [[Urban legend|urban myth]] that he was previously [[Adolf Hitler]]'s "pet alligator." Born in 1936 in the state of [[Mississippi]], [[United States]], Saturn soon was brought to [[Germany]], residing at the [[Berlin Zoological Garden]]. It was here his association with Adolf Hitler originated, as Hitler reportedly enjoyed visiting the zoo and especially liked the alligator. However, while Hitler may have viewed Saturn at the zoo, he was never Hitler's personal pet. During [[World War II]], the Berlin zoo was destroyed, but Saturn was discovered by British soldiers, who then gave the alligator to the Soviets in 1946. He has lived at the Moscow Zoo ever since, and has become one of the zoo's most famous and popular attractions. == Physical description == Saturn has been described as 2{{Cite web|url=http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/RUSSIA-MOSCOW-ZOO-ALLIGATOR/a7b1d311f06766cef490b9b113577f97?query=berlin+wall¤t=15&orderBy=Relevance&hits=29&referrer=search&search=/search?query=berlin%2520wall&allFilters=Lifestyle:Subject,APTN:Source&allFilters=Lifestyle:Subject,APTN:Source&productType=IncludedProducts&page=1&b=577f97|title=RUSSIA: MOSCOW ZOO: ALLIGATOR {{!}} AP Archive|last=|first=|date=24 December 2000|website=www.aparchive.com|access-date=27 February 2017}} to 3.5{{Cite news|url=http://www.stern.de/panorama/wissen/natur/kriegsbeute-saturn-kinder-duerfen-ihn-auch-schon-mal-piesacken-3294264.html|title=Kinder dürfen ihn auch schon mal piesacken|last=Albes|first=Andreas|date=9 May 2005|work=stern.de|access-date=27 February 2017|language=de-DE|trans-title=Children may even peck him}} meters long, and weighing 200 kilograms (441 pounds). Like the majority of alligators, he has green scales, a broad mouth, and yellow eyes. == Biography == Saturn was born of the wild in [[Mississippi]], [[United States]], in 1936. He was captured that year and was shipped to Berlin, where he was brought to the [[Berlin Zoological Garden]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.moscowzoo.ru/about-zoo/articles/stati-o-zhivotnykh/boris-akunin-saturn-pochti-ne-viden/|title=Борис Акунин "Сатурн почти не виден"|last=Akunin|first=Boris|date=|website=www.moscowzoo.ru|trans-title=Saturn is almost invisable|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219122840/http://moscowzoo.ru/about-zoo/articles/stati-o-zhivotnykh/boris-akunin-saturn-pochti-ne-viden/|archive-date=2015-02-19|dead-url=yes|access-date=27 February 2017}}{{Cite web|url=https://de.sputniknews.com/panorama/20170127314293922-moskau-alligator-hitler/|title=Kannte er Hitler? Zoo Moskau weiß nichts von brauner Vergangenheit seines Alligatoren|last=|first=|date=27 January 2017|website=de.sputniknews.com|language=de|trans-title=Did he know Hitler? Moscow Zoo knows nothing about the dark past of its alligator|access-date=27 February 2017}} It was from this period that the popular [[rumor]] emerged that Saturn was [[Adolf Hitler]]'s "pet."{{Cite news|url=https://deutsch.rt.com/gesellschaft/45915-letzte-deutsche-kriegsgefangene-alligator-saturn-moskau/|title=Der letzte deutsche Kriegsgefangene: Alligator "Saturn" im Moskauer Zoo|last=|first=|date=|work=RT Deutsch|access-date=27 February 2017|language=de|trans-title=The last German war prisoner: Alligator "Saturn" in the Moscow zoo}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-Kt6DQAAQBAJ&pg=PA9&lpg=PA9&dq=saturn+alligator+hitler&source=bl&ots=mazlgoeMF1&sig=CuW6cIsIPb0CYlE2quqTmI6EQwc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiFhZHqkq7SAhUD92MKHd3GCtk4ChDoAQg7MAU#v=onepage&q=saturn%20alligator%20hitler&f=false|title=1000 Facts about Animals Vol. 1|last=Egan|first=James|publisher=Lulu.com|isbn=9781326785079|language=en}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1Lt3DQAAQBAJ&pg=PA12&lpg=PA12&dq=saturn+alligator+hitler&source=bl&ots=YjP7H0Q43O&sig=UOqMaIeO3N5pOh_1qGE-gtJnMfQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiFhZHqkq7SAhUD92MKHd3GCtk4ChDoAQhEMAc#v=onepage&q=saturn%20alligator%20hitler&f=false|title=3000 Facts About Animals|last=Egan|first=James|publisher=Lulu.com|isbn=9781326723729|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.nearlyfirst.com/2015/07/28/hitlers-pet-alligator-is-85-and-living-in-moscow/|title=Hitler’s pet alligator is 85 and living in Moscow – Nearly First|date=5 March 2016|work=archive.is|access-date=27 February 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20160305073521/http://www.nearlyfirst.com/2015/07/28/hitlers-pet-alligator-is-85-and-living-in-moscow/|archivedate=5 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} This may have originated with the author [[Boris Akunin]], a Russian writer who hypothesized in an article that this may have been the case.{{Cite news|url=http://rusversion.info/society/238-alligator-from-the-moscow-zoo-were-suspected-of-having-links-with-hitl.html|title=Alligator from the Moscow zoo were suspected of having links with Hitler|access-date=27 February 2017|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://naewu.com/assets/pdf/news/advertising-and-pr-campaign-of-the-moscow-zoo-1.pdf|title=Advertising and PR-campaign of the Moscow Zoo|last=|first=|date=|website=Naewu.com|access-date=26 February 2017}}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In actuality, he was not Hitler's personal pet, as he was on public display at the zoo.{{Cite news|url=http://rbth.com/arts/2017/02/22/legends-of-the-moscow-zoo-reptilian-rumors-and-killer-crocs_707748|title=Legends of the Moscow Zoo: Reptilian rumors and killer crocs|last=Levkovich|first=Yevgeny|date=24 February 2017|work=Russia Beyond The Headlines|access-date=27 February 2017|language=en-US}} However, some sources report his display at the zoo as being part of a personal menagerie of Hitler's,{{Cite news|url=http://360tv.ru/news/pitomca-iz-lichnogo-zverinca-gitlera-snova-mozhno-uvidet-v-moskovskom-zooparke-18460/|title=Трофейного крокодила Гитлера снова можно увидеть в Московском зоопарке|last=|first=|date=|work=Телеканал 360|access-date=27 February 2017|language=ru-RU|trans-title=Trophy crocodile Hitler can be seen again in the Moscow Zoo}} while Dmitry Vasilyev, a veterinarian at the Moscow Zoo, contends that while Saturn was not Hitler's pet, the two certainly came into contact, as Hitler was known to have visited the Berlin Zoo on occasion. During [[World War II]], much of the Berlin Zoo was destroyed. Of the zoo's 16,000 animals, only 96 survived. When the [[aquarium]] building was destroyed by a bomb on 23 November 1943, 20 to 30 alligators and crocodiles were killed. Press reports documented that the streets near the aquarium were littered with alligator and [[crocodile]] corpses, but that some, including Saturn, had survived and were wandering through the city in search of food. At the close of the war, the area where the Berlin Zoo is located came under the jurisdiction of the [[British Zone of Occupation]]. In 1946, British soldiers discovered Saturn, and brought him to [[Leipzig]], then part of the [[Soviet occupation zone|Soviet Zone of Occupation]], where they gave Saturn to the Soviets.{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/ultimatemoscowguide/posts/134735677008163:0|title=The last prisoner - Adolf Hitler’s pet... - Ultimate moscow guide {{!}} Facebook|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=27 February 2017}} While the exact details of how Saturn came to Russia are unknown since the [[Moscow]] tourist office burnt down in the 1950s, it is known that the [[Red Army]] transported Saturn, along with an [[Python molurus|Indian python]], to Moscow in July 1946, and brought him to live in the [[Moscow Zoo]].{{Cite news|url=http://old.themoscowtimes.com/sitemap/free/1994/2/article/130-years-of-history-at-the-city-zoo/351143.html|title=130 Years of History at the City Zoo|last=Dukess|first=Karen|date=15 February 1994|work=The Moscow Times|access-date=26 February 2017}} When the alligator arrived at the Moscow Zoo, he was instantly a popular attraction, as there were only two crocodiles at the zoo and no other alligators. His German origins earned him the nickname 'Hitler', but he was later given the name 'Saturn'. In 1993, when Russian tanks were moving down the [[Garden Ring]] after the [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union|collapse of the Soviet Union]], Saturn cried out because of the vibrations, which a zookeeper thinks reminded him of the [[Battle of Berlin]]. In the 1950s, the United States gave the Soviet Union a younger, female alligator as a gift. She was named Shipka, and she and Saturn began [[mating]], although they did not produce any offspring, as all the eggs Shipka produced have been infertile. Shipka, who was thirty years younger than Saturn, later died, and Saturn was so distressed by her death that he refused food for a time. By 2005, Saturn had a new mate, who was then thirty years old. In his time at the Moscow Zoo, Saturn has had several narrow escapes from death. In the 1980s, a slab of concrete fell from the aquarium's ceiling into the alligator enclosure, but luckily for Saturn, he had made his way to a protective niche beforehand. In 1990, a new aquarium building was built, but Saturn resisted the move, refusing to eat for four months and becoming close to death. Once, a drunk visitor threw a boulder on his head to wake him up, after which zoo veterinarians fought to keep him alive for months. Another time, a group of tourists threw glass bottles at Saturn, injuring him. After these incidents, the enclosure was made more secure with the addition of thick glass wall. In the 2010s, Saturn once again stopped eating, this time for nearly a year. Zoo staff took blood samples for analysis, and injected him with vitamins to try to keep him alive. He did eventually resume eating. Today, Saturn spends much of his time sleeping. He eats a diet of fish, rabbits, and rats twice a week. Vladimir Kudriavzew, the head of the Moscow Zoo's reptile department, says that not many visitors today know of Saturn's eventful history. Today, zoo staff only relate Saturn's German origins to groups of visiting schoolchildren. When school classes come, the zookeepers allow children to stick the end of a broomstick into the enclosure, which is safe because Saturn is known as generally peaceful. His only violent incident occurred in 1970, when he tried to bite an inexperienced warden who had tried to feed him by hand. In 2015, the Moscow Zoo renovated the Terrarium, where the alligator enclosure is located.{{Cite web|url=http://moscowzoo.su/about-zoo/news/novosti-zooparka/our-terrarium-has-opened-after-reconstruction/|title=Our Terrarium has opened after reconstruction|last=|first=|date=|website=moscowzoo.su|publisher=Moscow Zoo|access-date=26 February 2017}} A new interior and reconstructed enclosure was completed, and Saturn returned to public display. Also in 2015, Saturn became sponsored by the French clothing company [[Lacoste]]. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/RUSSIA-MOSCOW-ZOO-ALLIGATOR/a7b1d311f06766cef490b9b113577f97?query=berlin+wall¤t=15&orderBy=Relevance&hits=29&referrer=search&search=%2Fsearch%3Fquery%3Dberlin%2520wall%26allFilters%3DLifestyle%3ASubject%2CAPTN%3ASource&allFilters=Lifestyle%3ASubject%2CAPTN%3ASource&productType=IncludedProducts&page=1&b=577f97 Associated Press video footage of Saturn] * [https://deutsch.rt.com/gesellschaft/45915-letzte-deutsche-kriegsgefangene-alligator-saturn-moskau/ RT video footage of Saturn] [[Category:1936 animal births]] [[Category:Animals as diplomatic gifts]] [[Category:Animals in politics]] [[Category:Berlin Zoological Garden]] [[Category:Individual crocodilians]] [[Category:Individual animals in Germany]] [[Category:Individual animals in Russia]] [[Category:Individual animals in the United States]] [[Category:Urban legends]]

{{Infobox company | name = Smart Start LLC | logo = | type = | industry = Automotive accessories | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = {{Start date and age|1993}} in [[Irving, Texas]], [[United States of America]] | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = | hq_location_country = | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = DUI prevention interlocks | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = Seven Inc. | website = <!-- {{URL|www.smartstartinc.com}} --> }} '''Smart Start, Inc.''' is a [[Texas]] company that provides services and technologies that prevent [[Drunk drivers|intoxicated drivers]] from operating a vehicle. Smart Start, Inc. manufactures, installs, monitors and services the [[Ignition system|ignition]] [[Ignition interlock device|interlock devices]]. In almost all cases, these devices are installed by court order due to [[Driving under the influence|DUI]] or [[DWI]] violations.
Smart Start, Inc. was founded in 1993 by Jay and Bettye Rodgers and is headquartered in [[Irving, Texas]]. In 2016 the company filed a lawsuit against the [[Minnesota Department of Public Safety|Minnesota DPS]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://kstp.com/news/interlock-ignition-gps-tracking-minnesota-department-of-public-safety-smart-start-breathalyzer-law-/4326401/|title=Lawsuit Claims Minnesota Department of Public Safety Violated Constitutional Rights of Ignition Interlock Users|work=KSTP|access-date=2017-07-30|language=en}}</ref> The company alleges that the use of GPS trackers to track persons convicted of DUI violates the [[Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourth Amendement]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://minnlawyer.com/2017/01/12/ignition-interlock-data-public-commissioner-admits/|title=Ignition interlock data public, commissioner admits – Minnesota Lawyer|last=Featherly|first=Kevin|access-date=2017-07-30}}</ref>
Smart Start claims to have installed over 200,000 ignition interlock devices and reports that these devices have prevented over 7 million vehicle starts due to potential drivers being over the approved limit.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.smartstartinc.com/index.php/products/in-house | title=Smart Start IN-HOM? Alcohol Monitoring System | accessdate=May 12, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130202205353/http://www.smartstartinc.com/index.php/products/in-house | archivedate=February 2, 2013 | df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/minnesota-legislators-say-they-ll-introduce-bill-over-location-tracking-ignition-systems/406139246/|title=Minnesota legislators say they'll introduce bill over location-tracking ignition systems|work=Star Tribune|access-date=2017-07-30}}</ref> The devices are in use in [[Canada]], the United States, and [[Australia]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/life-really-blows-for-growing-number-of-drivers-on-alcohol-interlock-program-20161211-gt8o92.html|title=Life really blows for growing number of drivers on alcohol interlock program|last=Carey|first=Adam|date=2016-12-11|work=The Age|access-date=2017-07-30|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Mandatory installation== {{main|Ignition interlock device}} Beginning in 2018, drivers convicted of DUI in Nevada are only eligible for reinstatement of driving privileges if they install an ignition interlock for 90 days after an arrest and for 6 months after a conviction.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Whaley|first1=Sean|title=MADD celebrates signing of Nevada DUI law|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/2017-legislature/madd-celebrates-signing-of-nevada-dui-law/|accessdate=6 August 2017|publisher=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=Jun 13, 2017}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} Subsistence crisis can be defined as an extreme situation where the basic means of livelihood are endangered. In France, due to the rapid expansion of the population from 23 million in 1715 to 28 million in 1789, a subsistence crisis occurred. A '''subsistence crisis''' is a crisis caused by economic factors (generally high food prices), which in turn may be caused by either natural or man-made factors,<ref name=Helsinki>"The European subsistence crisis of 1845-1850: a comparative perspective", http://www.helsinki.fi/iehc2006/papers3/Vanhaute.pdf, 20 June 2012</ref> which threatens the food supplies and the survival prospects of large numbers of people (it is considered [[famine]] if it is extremely severe and large numbers of lives are lost). A subsistence crisis can be considered genuine if it is visible in [[demographic]] data.
It was in France that the notion of a '''subsistence crisis''' was first formulated by Meuvret in 1946, and greatly popularised by Goubert in 1960 through his influential study of the Beauvaisis in [[Beauvais]].<ref name=Cambridge>Walter, John, and Roger S. Schofield. "Famine, Disease and the Social Order in Early Modern Society". Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1989. Print., https://books.google.com/books?id=uCERvGiMYdIC&lpg=PA189&dq=france%20subsistence%20crisis&pg=PA48#v=onepage&q=france%20subsistence%20crisis&f=false</ref> The theory of subsistence crises, in its contemporary guise, was first formulated by Meuvret in 1946. As an economic historian and specialist in price history Meuvret was struck by the coincidence between high prices and the increase in the number of deaths in the region of Gien in 1709–10. He then posed the problem of the nature of demographic crises, very tentatively at first, since he thought it was a hopeless quest to try to distinguish statistically between phenomena that were so closely associated: namely, mortality through simple inanition (starvation); mortality caused by disease, though attributable to malnutrition; and mortality by contagion, which in turn was linked to the scarcity that helped both spawn diseases and spread them through the migration of poor beggars.<ref name=Cambridge />
==Examples of subsistence crises== *The one prior to the [[French revolution]], in which two years of [[crop failures]] and [[Crop yield|low yields]] caused a [[grain]] shortage. *The [[Great Famine of 1315–1317]] *The [[Great Famine (Ireland)|Great Famine]] in Ireland. By the mid-1800s, the Irish had been living for decades in extreme poverty, which worsened the repeated and total failure of the potato crop, the [[starvation]], which was worsened by the [[Colony|colonial]] [[British Empire]] with ineffective [[famine relief projects]], [[evictions]] and [[emigration]] under duress, which often led to illness.
==See also== * [[Famine]]

Spanish | budget = | gross = }} '''''The Black Pimpernel''''' ({{lang-sv|Svarta nejlikan}}; {{lang-es|El Clavel negro}}) is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] drama film directed by [[Ulf Hultberg]] and starring [[Michael Nyqvist]] and [[Lisa Werlinder]]. The film also features [[Kate Del Castillo]], [[Luis Gnecco]] and [[Claire Ross-Brown]] in a minor part. The film is about [[Harald Edelstam]], Sweden’s ambassador to [[Chile]], who after the military coup of [[Augusto Pinochet]] in 1973, managed to save the lives of more than 1,300 people by taking them to his embassy and transporting them to Sweden. His name comes from the fictional hero [[The Scarlet Pimpernel]] who saved many lives during the [[French Revolution]]. The film was shot in Chile in the spring of 2006 and opened September 14, 2007. ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0796206}} * {{Sfdb title}} * {{YouTube|VtOPgjy5mrY|The Movie Trailer}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Black Pimpernel, The}} [[Category:Swedish films]] [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Spanish-language films]] [[Category:Films about Latin American military dictatorships]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films set in Chile]] [[Category:Films set in 1973]] {{Sweden-film-stub}}

{{orphan|date=July 2017}} '''The Black Woman Is God''' is a recurring group exhibition of Black women artists curated by Karen Seneferu and Melorra Green, which started in 2013 and in 2016 and 2017 has been located at the San Francisco city-owned nonprofit art space [[SOMArts]]. The exhibitions challenge a popular western mindset of [[God]] as a white male and instead explores new images showing "The Black Woman is God".
== History ==
=== 2013 Exhibition at the African American Art & Culture Complex === The first iteration of The Black Woman is God was intended as a solo exhibition for Seneferu, curated by Green, at the African American Art & Culture Complex. Seneferu agreed to participate in the exhibition only if other black female artists were included<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/art/article/A-room-full-of-art-affirms-The-Black-Woman-Is-8392070.php|title=A room full of art affirms ‘The Black Woman Is God’|work=SFGate|access-date=2017-07-21}}</ref>. The exhibition included 20 visual and performance artists. The opening reception also included a performing arts show as part of the exhibition and was called "vibrant and magnificent".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://sfbayview.com/2013/04/the-black-woman-is-god/|title=‘The Black Woman Is God’|work=San Francisco Bay View|access-date=2017-07-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://sfbayview.com/2013/05/the-black-woman-is-god-part-ii/|title=‘The Black Woman Is God’ – Part II|work=San Francisco Bay View|access-date=2017-07-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://peopleseye.photoshelter.com/gallery-collection/The-Black-Woman-Is-God/C0000Lih_hWEMNkk|title=The Black Woman Is God {{!}} PEOPLE'S EYE PHOTOGRAPHY|website=peopleseye.photoshelter.com|access-date=2017-07-27}}</ref>
=== 2016 Exhibition === The second, expanded iteration of The Black Woman is God, with 60 artists<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oaklandpost.org/2017/07/14/80-women-artists-annual-black-woman-god-exhibit/|title=80 Women Artists Showcased in Annual “Black Woman Is God” Exhibit|last=|date=2017-07-14|website=Oakland Post|access-date=2017-07-21}}</ref>, opened on July 7, 2016 and ran through August 16, 2016.
Art critics called it as "timely", "organic"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://afropunk.com/2016/07/feature-new-exhibit-the-black-woman-is-god-crucially-illustrates-the-social-activism-and-creativity-following-female-artists-of-color/|title=FEATURE: New exhibit 'The Black Woman is God' crucially illustrates the social activism and creativity following female artists of color - AFROPUNK|date=2016-07-01|work=AFROPUNK|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en-US}}</ref>, and "vivid"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cocoafly.com/2016/08/the-black-woman-is-god-is-beautiful.html|title=‘The Black Woman Is God’ is a Beautiful, Spiritual Experience|website=www.cocoafly.com|access-date=2017-07-21}}</ref>. Sheila Bapat of [[Bitch (magazine)|Bitch Magazine]] said "The exhibit intentionally turns the historic devaluation of Black women and their contributions—social, political, economical—on its head. This exhibit asserts Black women’s power and beauty and does not seek to devalue any other group in the process..... It applies pressure to the beliefs and values undergirding the laws and policies that exclude Black women’s lives from economic policymaking and their labor from economic value and protection."
=== 2017 Exhibition === The third iteration of The Black Woman is God, also curated by Karen Seneferu and Melorra Green, returned to SOMArts on July 20, 2017, running through August 26, 2017. The exhibition has the work of 80 artists on view.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.somarts.org/theblackwomanisgod2017|title=The Black Woman is God, July 20–August 26, 2017 — SOMArts|website=www.somarts.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oaklandpost.org/2017/07/14/80-women-artists-annual-black-woman-god-exhibit/|title=80 Women Artists Showcased in Annual “Black Woman Is God” Exhibit|last=by|date=2017-07-14|website=Oakland Post|access-date=2017-07-21}}</ref> SOMArts, the [[California Digital Library]] and [[Art Practical]] held a Wikipedia Edit-a-Thon on July 22 in conjunction with the exhibition "to raise the online visibility of Black women artists and challenge the gaps in art history that erase or minimize Black women’s contributions as artists, activists and social change-makers."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.somarts.org/theblackwomanisgodwikipedia/|title=The Black Woman is God Wikipedia Edit-a-thon|website=www.somarts.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-26}}</ref>
They plan for 2018 to have more events in Oakland where many artists live and would like future exhibitions to travel around the country and the world.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/entertainment/article/Black-female-creativity-celebrated-at-SOMArts-11959100.php|title=Black female creativity celebrated at SOMArts|work=San Francisco Chronicle|access-date=2018-04-09}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}

{{Infobox theatre | name =The first
Théâtre de l’Ambigu-Comique
(1769-1827) | image = Louis Léopold Boilly - L'entrée du théâtre.jpg | image_size = 280px | image_alt = | caption = The entrance to the Théâtre de l'Ambigu-Comique on the day of a free show. [[Louis-Léopold Boilly]] (1819) | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_caption = | address = 62 [[boulevard du Temple]],Colette 1983, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ap4XAQAAIAAJ&q=%2262+boulevard+du+Temple%22+ambigu&dq=%2262+boulevard+du+Temple%22+ambigu&hl=en&ei=ZuVVTr2VCIniiAKf6LCpCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CD8Q6AEwBA p. 79].
[[11th arrondissement of Paris|11th arrondissement]]
{{coord|48.8670|2.3651}} | city = Paris | country = | designation = | latitude = | longitude = | architect = | owner = | tenant = | operator = | capacity = | type = | opened = 9 July 1769 | reopened = | yearsactive = | rebuilt = | closed = burnt down 13 July 1827 | demolished = | othernames = Les Comédiens de Bois | production = | currentuse = | website = }} The '''Théâtre de l’Ambigu-Comique''' ({{IPA-fr|teɑtʁ də lɑ̃biɡy kɔmik|pron}}, literally, Theatre of the Comic-Ambiguity), a former Parisian theatre, was founded in 1769 on the [[boulevard du Temple]] immediately adjacent to the [[Théâtre de Nicolet]]. It was rebuilt in 1770 and 1786, but in 1827 was destroyed by fire. A new, larger theatre with a capacity of 2,000 as compared to the earlier 1,250 was built nearby on the boulevard Saint-Martin at its intersection with the rue de Bondy and opened the following year.McCormick 1993, pp. 18–19. The theatre was eventually demolished in 1966. ==History of the first theatre in the boulevard du Temple== It was founded in 1769 on the [[boulevard du Temple]], originally known as the Promenades des Ramparts, in Paris by [[Nicolas-Médard Audinot]], formerly a comedian of the [[Opéra-Comique]], which he had left to become a puppet-master at the Paris fairs. Audinot had already been a success in one of the sites of the [[Saint-Germain Fair]], where his large [[marionette]]s (called "bamboches") were in vogue. Under the name of his foundation, the "Comédiens de bois", the Opéra-Comique proposed [[pantomime]]s and "féeries" (spectacles), then he enlarged his repertoire to include marionettes, child-performers, and [[acrobatics|acrobat]]s, in comedies, [[vaudeville]] shows, "opéras comiques", dramas and pantomimes. The variety and mix of these theatrical modes justified and explained changing the theatre's name, after only one year, from "Comédiens de bois" to "Ambigu-Comique" when Audinot substituted child-performers for marionettes. Audinot also used wooden puppets to spitefully reenact his former colleagues from the Comédie Italienne. Audinot saved the profits he made from shows and constructed a permanent theatre building on the Boulevard du Temple, which officially opened on July 9, 1769.Hemmings 1994, p. 31. The following April, Audinot added to his puppets with a few young children, who he trained up in the theatrical arts, and painted the motto "Sicut infantes audi nos" on the theatre's curtain. His success caused [[Jacques Delille|Delille]] to write "Dear Audinot, childhood attired as old age". The architectural success of the theatre was mostly due to the ambitious and inventive set designer, Louis Daguerre. Daguerre, who is also credited with developing early photography and diorama theatre (1822), was an expert in scenic and lighting design and created picturesque effects within the theatre. [[Image:Plans of the theatres Ambigu-Comique and Gaîté on the Boulevard du Temple - Carlson 1966 p226.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Plans of the Ambigu-Comique (left) and the Théâtre de [[Jean-Baptiste Nicolet|Nicolet]] ([[Théâtre de la Gaîté (boulevard du Temple)]], right), on the boulevard du Temple.

The Ambigu-Comique and the Gaîté had a smaller number of boxes for privileged clientele than other Parisian theatres. These were separated by only half partitions that were more steeply angled toward the stage. The boxes usually found at the rear of a theatre were replaced with galleries of benches which seated more people. These arrangements provided more patrons with a better view of the stage, rather than a view of the other members of the audience.Carlson 1966, p. 226; McCormick 1993, p. 19.]] A Conseil decision of 1771 (demanded by the Opéra) banned singing, dancing, and having more than four musicians aroused such emotion that it was revoked only a few days later, and Audinot took full advantage of the situation. Judging, in 1772, that the time was right to extend the building, he gave up puppetry altogether, replacing them entirely with child-performers. Not entirely released from the ties which had brought about his rise in the large theatres, from 1780 he had to pay the Opéra a fee for representation and to engage him but not use him, in producing ballets and lyric pieces borrowed for that scene, whose shows had at least ten years of publicity. The Comédie-Française and the Comédie-Italienne stipulated, for their part, that dialogue pieces in the repertoire would be submitted to them before being played, so they could edit and change them to their own advantage. Despite these problems and burdens, the Ambigu was able to rebuild and enlarge its theatre in 1786. Audinot sustained the fashion for "pantomimes historiques and "pantomimes romanesques" such as "Belle au bois dormant", "Masque de fer", "Forêt-Noire", and "Capitaine Cook". The Ambigu's success was equally down to the "comédies graveleuses" written by its official writers [[Roger-Timothée Régnard de Pleinchesne|Plainchesne]] and [[Pierre-Louis Moline|Moline]]. [[Louis Petit de Bachaumont|Bachaumont]] even noted in 1771 that Audinot's theatre was better attended than the Opéra. Being located on the Boulevard du Temple amongst several other successful theaters created a healthy competition and a spark that the Ambigu used to strive to achieve greatness. Some of the theaters along the Boulevard included Theatre de Nicolet, Theatre des Associes, Theatre des Delassement-Comiques, and many others. The Comedie Francais, which was established back in 1680 and was certainly well-known throughout Europe, coexisted with the Ambigu and, therefore, they competed each other for an audience. However, l’Ambigu’s biggest rival was Théâtre Feydeau. The Feydeau was closed by the government due to the social “turbulence” it invoked, and on February 3, 1795 Théâtre de l’Ambigu showed a production of "Le Concert de la rue Feydeau." This production was a satirical piece and a supposedly “lighthearted attack” against The Feydeau which was taken the wrong way to many viewers and caused “angry crowds to surround the Ambigu for two evenings until the Committee of Public Saftety demanded that the play be withdrawn in the interests of public tranquility” (Carlson.) The proclamation of the freedom of the theatres in 1791 gave rise to a large number of rivals to the Ambigu, which was forced to close in 1799. In 1801, Audinot inaugurated a [[melodrama]] with [[Guilbert de Pixérécourt]], [[Louis-Charles Caigniez|Caigniez]] and [[Victor Henri-Joseph Brahain Ducange|Victor Ducange]]. In addition to the big name of Pixerecourt, actor Frederick Lemaitre played “Robert Macaire,” a classic villain in many French plays, in 1823 with outstanding success. After Audinot stepped down as the director, one of the company’s actors named Picardeaux took over, followed by Andre Coffin-Rosny, then Hector Chaussier, and another actor, Cammaile Saint-Aubin. The Ambigu's building burned down on 13 July 1827. {{Clear}} ==History of the second theatre in the boulevard Saint-Martin== {{Infobox theatre | name =The second
Théâtre de l’Ambigu-Comique
(c. 1827-1966) | image = Ambigutheatre.jpg | image_size = 280px | image_alt = | caption = The Théâtre de l'Ambigu-Comique
on the boulevard Saint-Martin | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_caption = | address = 2 boulevard Saint-Martin,Dickens 1882, [https://books.google.com/books?id=4LIMAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA254#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 254].
[[10th arrondissement of Paris|10th arrondissement]]
{{coord|48.86860|2.35928|type:landmark_region:FR}} | city = [[Paris]] | country = | designation = | latitude = | longitude = | architect = | owner = | tenant = | operator = | capacity = | type = | opened = 7 June 1828 | reopened = | yearsactive = | rebuilt = | closed = | demolished = 1966 | othernames = | production = | currentuse = | website = }} The theatre was rebuilt to plans by the architects [[Jacques Ignace Hittorff]] and [[Jean-François-Joseph Lecointe]] on the [[boulevard Saint-Martin]], at the corner of [[rue de Bondy]] (now [[rue René-Boulanger]]). The 19th century saw the Ambigu's success augmented, so much so that its grand spectacles, dramas, melodramas, "[[boulevard theatre (aesthetic)|pièces de boulevard]]" and vaudeville shows remain the most faithful representation of the dramatic traditions of what is called "the [[Boulevard du Crime|boulevard of crime]]" ("le boulevard du crime"). Productions of adapted novels were successful such as Émile Zola’s ''L’Assommoir'' in 1879 and ''Nana'' in 1881. [[Image:Albert Guillaume - Gigolette.jpg|thumb|left|160px|Poster for an 1896 production at the Theâtre]] ===20th century=== In the 1920s, the building was briefly turned into a cinema. In 1954, the comedian [[Christian Casadesus]] reopened the Théâtre de l'Ambigu, and plays were staged there once again, by contemporary authors such as [[François Billetdoux]] and [[Roger Vitrac]]. In 1966, despite several demonstrations and a spectacular parade by the whole theatrical profession, the theatre was closed for good and demolished. The department of [[André Malraux]], minister of culture, promised that the auditorium, then the whole building, would be preserved, when demolition works had already begun. {{Clear}} ==See also== *[[Suzanne Lagier]] == References == ;Notes {{Reflist}} ;Sources * Brazier, Nicholas (1838). ''Histoire des petits théâtres de Paris depuis leur origine'' {{fr icon}}, Paris: Allardin. [https://books.google.com/books?id=gcA9AAAAYAAJ&pg=PR3#v=onepage&q&f=false View] at [[Google Books]]. * Bonnassies, Jules (1875). ''Les Spectacles forains et la Comédie Française'' {{fr icon}}. Paris: E. Dentu. [https://books.google.com/books?id=tNQLAAAAIAAJ&pg=PP13#v=onepage&q&f=false View] at [[Google Books]]. * Carlson, Marvin (1966). ''The Theatre of the French Revolution''. Ithaca: Cornell University Press. {{OCLC|331216|559057440|622637342}}. * Colette, Marie-Noëlle (1983). ''La Musique à Paris en 1830-1831''. Paris: Bibliothèque Nationale. {{ISBN|978-2-7177-1656-6}}. * [[Charles Dickens, Jr.|Dickens, Charles]] (1882). ''Dickens's Dictionary of Paris''. London: Macmillan. [https://books.google.com/books?id=4LIMAAAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA1#v=onepage&q&f=false View] at [[Google Books]]. * Faul, Michel (2013). ''Les Tribulations de Nicolas-Médard Audinot, fondateur du théâtre de l'Ambigu-Comique''. Lyon: Symétrie. {{ISBN|978-2-914373-97-5}}. * Forman, Edward (2010). ''Historical Dictionary of French Theatre''. Lanham: Scarecrow Press, Inc. Print. * Hemmings, F. W. J. (1994). ''Theatre and State in France, 1760–1905''. New York: Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-521-03472-2}} (2006 reprint). * Jacob, P. L. (1844). ''Bibliotheque Dramatique de Monsieur De Soleinne'', vol. 3 {{fr icon}}. Paris: Administration de l'Alliance des Arts. [https://archive.org/stream/bibliothquedram01brungoog#page/n8/mode/2up View] at [[Internet Archive]]. * McCormick, John (1993). ''Popular Theatres of Nineteenth Century France''. New York: Routledge. {{ISBN|978-0-415-08854-1}}. * Planta, Edward (1821). ''A New Picture of Paris; or, The Stranger's Guide to the French Metropolis''. London: Samuel Lee and Baldwin, Craddock. [https://books.google.com/books?id=nEOBS9W9YzkC&pg=PR1#v=onepage&q&f=false View] at [[Google Books]]. * Vapereau, Gustave (1876). ''Dictionnaire universel des littératures'', pp. 76–77 {{fr icon}}. Paris: Hachette. [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k2207247/f91.image.r=.langEN View] at [[Gallica]]. * Wilson, Edwin; Goldfarb, Alvin (2008). ''History of the Living Theatre''. New York: McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc. Print. ==External links== {{Commons category|Théâtre de l'Ambigu-Comique}} * [http://cesar.org.uk/cesar2/places/places.php?fct=edit&location_UOID=101537 All the shows put on at the Ambigu-Comique (in the boulevard du Temple) in the 18th century] on the [http://cesar.org.uk CÉSAR] site {{DEFAULTSORT:Theatre De L'ambigu-Comique}} [[Category:Buildings and structures demolished in 1966]] [[Category:Former theatres in Paris|Ambigu-Comique]] [[Category:1769 establishments in France]] [[Category:1966 disestablishments]] [[Category:Theatres in the 10th arrondissement of Paris]] [[Category:11th arrondissement of Paris]] [[Category:Former buildings and structures in Paris]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1769]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1828]]

page.title: University of Hong Kong pro-vice-chancellor selection controversy

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=November 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} [[File:Johannes Chan Man-mun.jpg|thumbnail|Johannes Chan]] The '''University of Hong Kong pro-vice-chancellor selection controversy''' surrounds alleged political interference behind the [[University of Hong Kong]] governing council's rejection of [[Johannes Chan]]'s recommended appointment to the post of [[pro-vice-chancellor]] in charge of staffing and resources. Chan, dean of the [[University of Hong Kong Faculty of Law|Faculty of Law]] from 2002 until 2014, had been unanimously recommended for the post by a selection committee headed by university president [[Peter Mathieson (professor)|Peter Mathieson]]. The governing council's decision, the first time that a candidate selected by the committee has been rejected, is widely viewed as political retaliation for Chan's involvement with pro-democratic figures including his former subordinate [[Benny Tai]]. A majority of HKU Council members are not students or staff of the university, and many are directly appointed by incumbent HKSAR Chief executive [[Leung Chun-ying]]. The decision has received international condemnation, and is being viewed as part of a Beijing-backed curtailing of [[academic freedom]]s that will damage Hong Kong's academic reputation.<ref name=WSJ151007>{{cite news|title=Hong Kong University Purge: Pro-Beijing forces target a top school's leaders to intimidate professors|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/hong-kong-university-purge-1444261236|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=7 October 2015}} {{subscription required}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:Main Building of the University of Hong Kong and clock tower.JPG|thumbnail|The University of Hong Kong]]
=== Selection === All pro-vice-chancellors of the University of Hong Kong are recommended by a search committee comprising the university president and vice-chancellor and other members selected by the HKU Council.
The selection committee unanimously recommended the council appoint [[Johannes Chan]] to the pro-vice-chancellor post responsible for staffing and resources, a position that had been left vacant for five years.<ref name=hkfpexplainer>{{cite news|last1=Cheng|first1=Kris|title=Explainer: The HKU Council pro-vice-chancellor debacle|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2015/09/30/explainer-hku-council-rejects-johannes-chan-appointment-to-pro-vice-chancellor/|work=Hong Kong Free Press|date=30 September 2015}}</ref> Chan, who served as dean of the Faculty of Law from 2002 until 2014, is a distinguished scholar in constitutional law and human rights and "a vocal critic on Hong Kong's political reform issues".<ref name=scmpchan>{{cite news|last1=Ng|first1=Joyce|title=Johannes Chan's appointment vote at Hong Kong University: why it's a big deal|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/education-community/article/1862412/five-points-note-johannes-chans-appointment-vote|work=South China Morning Post|date=29 September 2015}}</ref><ref name=reuters1>{{cite news|last1=Pomfret|first1=James|title=Hong Kong university faces pressure from pro-Beijing opponents of liberal scholar|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/09/29/hongkong-university-idUSL3N11Z2TV20150929|agency=Reuters|date=29 September 2015}}</ref><ref name=meddling>{{cite news|last1=Liu|first1=Juliana|title=Beijing meddling claims over Hong Kong University post|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-china-blog-34398377|work=''BBC News''|date=30 September 2015}}</ref> Chan is the only honorary senior counsel of the [[Hong Kong Bar Association|Hong Kong Bar]], a title bestowed in 2003 light of his "pivotal role in the education of Hong Kong's future lawyers" and his commitment to upholding human rights.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bradford|first1=Sara|title=HK's first honorary senior counsel inducted|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/415111/hks-first-honorary-senior-counsel-inducted|work=South China Morning Post|date=11 May 2003}}</ref><ref name=scmp25sept/>
=== Concerted attack by pro-CPC media === Owing to his liberal political stance, criticism of Chan by media controlled by the Communist Party of China was stepped up as soon as his candidacy for the post became known.<ref name=hundreds>{{cite news|last1=Zhao|first1=Shirley|last2=Ng|first2=Joyce|title=Hundreds sign petition urging University of Hong Kong to end delay of liberal scholar's appointment|work=South China Morning Post|date=23 July 2015}}</ref> He was derided in ''[[Ta Kung Pao]]'' and ''[[Wen Wei Po]]'', which together published more than 350 articles attacking him and accusing him of "meddling in politics" for his involvement with pro-democratic figures including his former subordinate [[Benny Tai]].<ref name=hkfpexplainer/><ref name=straits>{{cite news|title=1,000 in silent HK uni protest to defend academic freedom|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/1000-in-silent-hk-uni-protest-to-defend-academic-freedom|work=[[The Straits Times]]|date=7 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Ng|first1=Joyce|title=HKU law professors unite to denounce Wen Wei Po attack on Johannes Chan|work=South China Morning Post|date=13 February 2015|page=A3}}</ref><ref name=ejinsightjuly2>{{cite news|title=HKU delays pro vice chancellor appointment – again|url=http://www.ejinsight.com/20150702-hku-delays-pro-vice-chancellor-appointment-again/|work=Hong Kong Economic Journal|date=2 July 2015}}</ref> Communist Party-controlled newspaper ''[[Global Times]]'' also bashed Chan, calling him a "ringleader" of the [[2014 Hong Kong protests|2014 pro-democratic protests]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Zeng|first1=Vivienne|title=State-run Global Times slams 'Occupy ringleader' Johannes Chan over HKU appointment row|url=https://www.hongkongfp.com/2015/09/30/state-run-global-times-slams-occupy-ringleader-johannes-chan-over-hku-appointment-row/|work=Hong Kong Free Press|date=30 September 2015}}</ref> Chan's treatment in Beijing-controlled media has been described as a [[smear campaign]] and [[character assassination]].<ref name=scmp25sept>{{cite news|last1=Cohen|first1=Jerome A.|last2=Cheung|first2=Alvin|title=Delay in HKU appointment of Johannes Chan makes a mockery of Beijing's pledged support for rule of law|work=South China Morning Post|date=25 September 2015}}</ref><ref name=chu>{{cite news|last1=Chu|first1=Winston Ka-sun|title=Bickering over HKU job raises fears about academic freedom|work=South China Morning Post|date=6 July 2015}}</ref><ref name=smeared/><ref name=forbes7oct>{{cite news|last1=Gonzalez|first1=Mike|title=China Doesn't Know How To Treat An International Financial Center|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mikegonzalez3/2015/10/07/china-doesnt-know-how-to-treat-an-international-financial-center/|work=Forbes|date=7 October 2015}}</ref>
===Council composition=== The HKU Council normally comprises 24 members, although in mid-2015 two seats were vacant and Margaret Leung served in two roles. Two further members, Yuen Kwok-yung and Aloysius Arokiaraj, resigned in July but continued to serve on the council until their replacements were elected. The council's ''Guide and Code of Practice'' includes a confidentiality clause. It was updated in August 2015 to state that "it is ''absolutely'' necessary to keep confidential the council agenda, supporting papers and minutes", while the previous version (from 2004) had stated less strictly, "it is ''normally'' necessary".<ref name=transparency/>
The decision not to appoint Chan is seen as a pro-government act of retaliation against "pro-democracy leaders and participants" and a blow to academic freedom.<ref name=scmpchan/><ref name=csm1/> This is partly because six members of the council are directly appointed by the [[Chief executive of Hong Kong]], who acts as chancellor of all publicly funded tertiary institutions in the territory.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lo|first1=Alex|title=Chief executive as chancellor of Hong Kong universities is an anachronism|url=http://www.scmp.com/comment/insight-opinion/article/1838191/chief-executive-chancellor-hong-kong-universities?page=all|work=South China Morning Post|date=13 July 2015}}</ref> Five members are delegates to the [[National People's Congress]] in Beijing, and as such are obliged to toe the Communist Party line or otherwise risk expulsion.<ref name=nytimes11>{{cite news|last1=Forsythe|first1=Michael|title=Vote at Hong Kong University Stirs Concern Over Beijing's Influence|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/01/world/asia/hong-kong-university-votes-against-promoting-johannes-chan.html|work=The New York Times|date=30 September 2015}}</ref> In overall council makeup, university students and staff are outnumbered by members from outside the university.<ref name=nytimes11/>
The composition of the council at the time of Chan's rejection was as follows:
